awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Targets of natural selection in reef-building corals
awd_abstract_narration:
Corals are the engineers, builders, and bricks of the most biologically diverse ecosystem in the ocean. Alarmingly, coral reefs worldwide are in decline, struggling to survive the effects of ongoing climate change. The future of coral reefs relies on the ability of corals to track global warming with evolutionary adaptation. This project will be the first to address genetics of coral adaptation in nature. Its overarching goal is to identify the genes that are modified by natural selection to help corals cope with the changing environment. The project will integrate comparative genomic, population genomic, and quantitative genetic approaches to build an inventory of such genes and to verify their effect on coral fitness. 

This project will elucidate fundamental mechanisms of evolution in the marine environment. It will also provide genetic markers to assess the risk of extinction of individual reefs, which will greatly help prioritizing conservation efforts to ensure the persistence of coral reefs in the future. In addition, there will be rich opportunities to enhance biodiversity education at the undergraduate level, promote basic science as a profession in K-12 schools, and raise public awareness of climate change.

por.por_cntn:
Will corals be able to survive the climate change? The key to answering this question is to understand the mechanisms by which corals adapt to changing environment and evaluate how fast this adaptation can happen. Our experiments relied on genomic analyses of genetic variation and gene activity in natural and experimental coral populations to identify genes and biological processes that helped corals match their physiological performance to different environments. To evaluate how fast these characteristics can evolve, we also investigated how much of their diversity was available to natural selection in coral populations, and how effectively they were passed down from parents to offspring. 

Our major findings are the following:

     1. Corals adapt to their local habitat very effectively and show extensive variation in genes and physiological processes responsible for the interaction with the environment.

     2. Fitness traits, such as thermal tolerance or ability to make stress-tolerant larvae, are highly heritable. Combined with the first finding, this implies that there is a lot of fuel for natural selection out there, potentially facilitating rapid evolution.

     3. We identified several genes involved in adaptation to temperature and higher risk of infection. These genes illuminate key aspects of coral biology and could be used as markers identify potential “winners in the game of climate change” for reef restoration programs.

    We continue investigating genomics of coral adaptation in nature using markers and tools developed within this project, aiming to track coral evolution to climate change as it happens before our eyes.

    Broader impacts of our work include the justification for the “assisted colonization” efforts to boost genetic resilience of natural coral populations, development of tools for early diagnosis of coral stress and disease, and introduction of a series of methodologies based on next-generation sequencing that can be used to study genomics of adaptation in any non-model organism. This project provided research experience to >20 undergraduates, was the main dissertation theme for three PhD students, and resulted in multiple public lectures, press releases and high-profile news reports. In addition, with this project we have pioneered the policy of rapid and unrestricted data sharing in coral genomics, which is now being followed by many labs around the world.
